'''Andrew 'Smokey' Hogg''' (January 27, 1914 - May 1, 1960)<ref name="amg">[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p87266/biography|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic biography - accessed January 2008]</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[post-war]] [[Texas blues|Texas]] and [[country blues]] [[musician]].

==Life and career==
Hogg was born near Westconnie, [[Texas]], [[United States]] and grew up on the farm and was taught to play [[guitar]] by his father Frank Hogg.  While still in his [[adolescence|teens]] he teamed up with the [[slide guitar]]ist and [[singer|vocalist]], B.K. Turner aka [[Black Ace]] and the pair travelled together playing the turpentine and logging camp circuit of country dance halls and juke joints that surrounded [[Kilgore, Texas|Kilgore]], [[Tyler, Texas|Tyler]], [[Greenville, Texas|Greenville]] and [[Palestine, Texas|Palestine]] in [[East Texas]].

In 1937 Smokey and Black Ace were brought to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] by [[Decca Records]] to [[sound recording and reproduction|record]], and Smokey had his first [[gramophone record]] ("Family Trouble Blues"/"Kind Hearted Blues") released, as by Andrew Hogg. It was an isolated occurrence - he did not make it back into a [[recording studio]] for over a decade.<ref name="amg"/> By the early 1940s Hogg was married and making a good living [[busking]] around the [[Deep Ellum, Dallas, Texas|Deep Ellum]] area of [[Dallas, Texas]].

Hogg was [[Conscription in the United States|drafted]] in the mid-1940s and after a brief spell with the [[United States|U.S.]] military, he continued working in the Dallas area where he was becoming well known. In 1947 he came to the attention of Herbert T. Rippa Sr, boss of the Dallas based [[record label]], Bluebonnet Records, who recorded several sides with him and leased the masters to [[Modern Records]].

The first release on Modern was the [[Big Bill Broonzy]] [[song]] "Too Many Drivers", and this racked up sufficient sales to encourage Modern Records to bring Hogg out to [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], [[California]] to cut more sides with their team of [[recording studio|studio]] [[session musician|musicians]]. These songs included his two biggest [[hit record|hits]], "Long Tall Mama" in 1949 and another Broonzy tune "[[Good Morning, School Girl|Little School Girl]]" (#9 U.S. [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]]  [[record chart|chart]]) in 1950.

His two-part "Penitentiary Blues" (1952) was a remake of the prison song, "Ain't No More Cane on the Brazos".<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 117–18
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>

Hogg's country blues style, influenced by Broonzy, [[Peetie Wheatstraw]] and Black Ace was popular with record buyers in the [[Southern United States|South]] during the late 1940s and early 1950s. He continued to work and record until the end of the 1950s, but died of [[cancer]], or possibly a ruptured [[Peptic ulcer|ulcer]], in [[McKinney, Texas]] in 1960.<ref>[http://www.thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1960.html Dead Rock Stars Club website - accessed January 2008]</ref>

==Relations and confusion==
Smokey's [[cousin]], John Hogg, also played the blues, recording for [[Mercury Records|Mercury]] in 1951.

Smokey was reputed to be a cousin of [[Lightnin' Hopkins]], and distantly related to [[Alger "Texas" Alexander]], although both claims are ambiguous.<ref>[http://www.thebluestrail.com/artists/mus_hogg.htm The Bluestrail.com website information]</ref> 

He is not to be confused with Willie "Smokey" Hogg, a [[New York City|New York]] based musician of the 1960s with a similar name.<ref name="amg"/>
